segments.text: Mr. Wiesen, first of all, would you tell us something about your early life, including the names of your parents, the dates of their birth and death, the places where they were born, the place where you were born, and the time of your birth, the schools you attended before you went to A&M?
I was born in Fort Worth in 1892.
My parents were married in 1890-some time.
Ninety, I believe it was.
And my father had been born in Berlin, and he came to this country, to Houston, Texas, when he was seven years old.
And the family moved to Baird, Texas.
At that time, the Texas Pacific was moving west, and it established a terminal at Baird, Texas.
And my grandfather, who was a professional engraver, moved there.
Of course, a watchmaker and
And Graver was kind of a lost affair in a cowboy town, but the kids, the children grew up there.
My father and his brother and three sisters.
And that was Baird?
Baird, Texas.
How was that spelled?
B-A-I-R-D in Callahan County.
It's about fifteen miles east of Appalachia.
And they lived there.
He built the first rock house in the country, and they lived there until all the children were grown and married.

And my father, of course, unable to go to school, he became a printer's devil, and that's where he learned the English language so that he could, later years, as a locomotive engineer and chairman for the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, he became, stayed in that position for some 30 years and died in 1920, 1920.
I've forgotten, 59 I believe.
No, it's 49.
And my mother lived on until 56.
Was your mother born in the United States?
She was born in East Texas, in Raines County, Texas, and the family had come there from Tennessee.
grain and water mill on the Sabine River back before the Civil War.
That was your mother's father?
Yeah, my mother's father.
There was a very large family, and a good many of them passed on.
But I was reared in Fort Worth itself, and I went to school there.
I was in high school from 1907 to 1911.
From there I went to work for a railroad company.
Which railroad?
Texas Pacific Railroad Company in the baggage and ticket department, and enlisted and enrolled in the business college.
This was in Fort Worth?
Fort Worth Brantley Drone Business College.
And for the next two years I was very active in that, and I had decided after
three years of working for the railroad company, which my father opposed very much, that I better think about going to college.
And I had a number of friends who had gone to A&M, and my father told me that if I would go to A&M and study agriculture, I could have the farm, which we had between Fort Worth and Dallas.
But that didn't weigh heavily in my decision, I just, because I knew so many people had gone to A&M.
I went to A&M at night, fall of 15, and everything was fine the freshman, sophomore year, and the junior year, of course, the war came, had already been in progress since 1914.
And when we got into it, I was eligible for the
Leon Springs training camp, but the doctor, what was his name, I can't remember, he talked me out of it, and so they wanted me to finish my course at college.

But it was very soon after the group of us got excited, and 57 of us went over to a pep meeting given by some Army recruiting officer, and before we knew what happened to us, we'd all enlisted in the Air Force.
First of all, let me ask a question before you go on.
Did you have to go through any special procedures to enter Texas A&M?
No.
I wrote down there, and they told me to come on down, and when I came in, old Reynolds met me at the station at 4 o'clock in the morning and took me up.
Foster Hall and then took me over that morning to the registrar's office.
Who was it that met you?
I think his name was Reynolds.
I can always remember him, but I don't remember his initials.
But he was in D Company, and so that's how I landed in D Company and Foster Hall.
He was down there looking for recruits for Foster Hall.
I see.
By going into Foster Hall, then, you ended up being in B Company.
Yes.
Did you have to send a transcript of your high school grades?
I brought that with me.
Did you receive any credit for the business courses that you had taken?
In fact, I had two deficiencies.
I dropped out the last two months of my senior year because I had
misunderstanding with my math teacher, who I'd been known all my life, and I felt that she and the principal let me down.
So I left school without finishing, so I had to make up those credits.
And I had a deficiency in math, which I made up first year.
Made a 99 in it more than I ever made before.
I remember that.
What were your first reactions to A&M and to College Station when you arrived
Well, you see, A&M was out in the country those days, and we served by two railroads only.
And it was isolated.
And I, being four years older than the average freshman, I was a little bit more mature looking back on it.
And I felt some restraints about being confined to the campus, which was very strict in those days.
And, of course, I brought up

at home to be disciplined at home all my life, and I was very strict about observing the restrictions, the regulations, and to go into town on Saturday, of course, you had to go on the trolley car, and there was nothing after you got there.
So I was a little bit uncomfortable, but the fact that there seemed so much
to do without any supervision or responsibility was a period of freedom to me.
I enjoyed the, I was told before I went there I wouldn't like the military, but the military didn't bother me until later in the year when the question of hazing came up.
And we had a good many diehards
in the upper classes on his hazing question, and there was considerable hazing went on.
Sub Rosen.
Well, the first I knew about it, one of the seniors came out and asked me what I thought about Bissell's speech on hazing, and I told him I agreed with it in that
put me on the blacklist in that group for the rest of the year.
I'm pretty sure, looking back on it, because I was, I didn't get run and hazed very much.
I was abused by one or two people, and the only person I ever hated in my life was the sophomore who cleared through the school, was one of the person who was very brutal to me.
And I intended to kill him one time.
I decided I was going to do that, but I got control of my senses enough to realize that these things were passing, and so nothing came of it.
But my sophomore year, I think, was my happiest year there.
I had, of course, many friends, and it was very pleasant.
Like some of the most more pleasant reflections I've had in a lot of years has been in that period of time.
And then when the time came to decide about going into the Army, this group of us that went in were thrown together in one area.
And that year, of course, was one of the very severe winters, and we had lots of sickness, and the flu epidemic broke out.
This was the flu epidemic on campus?
Yes.
They had some temporary buildings built around.
I couldn't locate them now.
I know where they were, but we had an influx of people from all over the north and east into this service company.
And our hospital was a new building, but it was not intended for such large numbers, and they couldn't accommodate all the people who were ill.
I was confined to Ross Hall, third floor, and I got the flu just right out of the blue.
I never went to hospital, and never saw the doctor, and after three or four weeks, I couldn't get out of bed.
And some women on the campus in the Home Economics Department inquired about me, and they told it.
They didn't even miss me out of the office, apparently, it was so much confusion.
I was assistant to the adjutant.
And these two women either paid or bribed or did,
arranged with these soldiers to get a litter and bring me down to their house on the campus.
And they set me up on this cot in their living room, and they started to work on me.
If they hadn't, I wouldn't have lived, because they were dying all around there, you know.
And those two people were Marty Higgins in the Home Economics Department, not the State Home Demonstration Agent, pardon me,
And Laura Neal was in charge.
And they were the two people that Laura Neal had been, that was a teacher in Fort Worth High School when I was a student there.
That's the reason I knew her, came to know her.
And Marty Higgins always said later that I was her fish because I always kept the house in repair on the campus.
Well, this was sort of an appreciation for taking care of you while you were sick, I think.
Indeed.
In fact, we were in contact all the years later.
She died at the age of 83, four years ago, in Arlington.
She had, while I was in China, she married E.E.
Davis, who was the first dean of the Arlington School, and they lived in Arlington.
But I'm getting ahead of myself in a way because on graduation,
We had no replacement service at that time, and it was always a headache for those graduating what they were going to do, those whose parents hadn't already provided a place for them.
And so I made the expression to the local Episcopal minister that I would like to go as far away
so far away from A&M to take $49 to send a postal card home.
And of course they laughed about that, and I have since.
And so the next day or two, he told me that they wanted somebody to teach school in Japan.
Well, I said, you know, I'm not fit for a teacher.
I don't have enough equipment for a teacher.
Well, he said the type of school they have there, you would probably wouldn't find too much difficulty.
If you want, I'll write to the board in New York and give them your name," and he did.

But in the meantime, I was given recommendations to various organizations, particularly in Dallas, and I went up to Plyford Shops, and I was told that I was, had good training, but I'd had no experience.
They couldn't use me.
I communicated this to Dean Kyle,
who was, I relied on for most of my information anyhow and advice.
And he told me to get on a train and go out to Fort Stockton and to take over a job of measuring water for one of the two first irrigation projects out there.
So it took an almost three-day trip by train I got to Fort Stockton and was taken out on the reservation there.
I stayed there until the following spring, when most of the work was done.
In the meantime, I was in contact with this fiscal board of missions, and they wanted me to go to China.
They, of course, laid out the plans, and I accepted that.
But I had to wait for the summer, so I took a job with the Cisco Chamber of Commerce.

on the way home back to Fort Worth and stayed there for four or five months with working with them on a drive to raise the bond issue, money for a bond issue to build a dam, which was done after I left.
So I got myself together and went to China.
I left on August 18th from Vancouver in 1920.

And six weeks later, I was in Shanghai, and I stayed with the mission school for the next two years, and decided that I needed to come home because I was only getting $70 a month, and I couldn't pay my taxes back home.
So I was telling my troubles to Dr. Washoe, who later became
famous in the Roosevelt administration for saving an American crew over in Java.
Dr. Waslow advised me to take the job in Hankow instead of going home.
Hankow was an international city across the river from Wuchang, the capital of Hubei province in China.
So I interviewed
manager of this dollar-a-rubber dollar company.
They had a big lumber yard and a big warehouse of railroad and firefighting equipment and things of that kind.
It was an import house.
And they sent me to Shanghai on the first trip to one of the most palatial river steamers that ever operated on the river.
Of course, a country boy from America, I was very much impressed with all of this.

So after a week of training in the Shanghai office, they sent me back to Hancao, and the managers, a year later, decided to retire and come home, and left me there, but they sent people from other parts of the world in there to operate the district manager over me.
And we sold lumber.
operated river steamers on the upper river, which was to me a very romantic operation, both profitable and dangerous, and exciting in other words.
But there I learned, put into practice all my knowledge of accounting, and I

of course, had to be active in the foreign community, which was predominantly British, but had Russians and not very many Germans at that time, but Japanese who were not socially acceptable in those days.
But we had a very pleasant colonial atmosphere under extraterritorial religion, and life was
the kind of life that a person might want to live today in retirement if they had the money to live like we lived there, because without much money we had very many luxuries.
Of course, plenty of servants and not much expense.
And that lasted for until the company reorganized around the World Service and gave preference to California people.

rather than people from other parts of the country, and my dissatisfaction was expressed to a close associate in another company, a firm that had been in China for a hundred years, a private firm, exporters of tung oil oil, or Chinese wood oil.
And they wanted me to come over there, and so I arranged with the company in Shanghai after they decided they were not going to give me a promotion of any kind.
And I went back upriver to Gillespie and Sons and became assistant manager there for the next four years.

We had operated the distributorship for the Ford Motor Company, and I was in charge of that program, which meant that I had to get out in the country to get towns to cooperate to build roads between towns and then sell them.

cars and build the bodies, truck bodies, I mean passenger bodies to go on, because commercial trucks were not quite out of the question at that time because it was cheap labor, but people wanted to ride.
So Pepper laid out these agencies and got the roads built, and then we sold, built the cars and sold the cars, and this program went on for
When I left in 27, when the Ford Motor Company went out of production, we had 50,000 miles of roads.
And the last project was the first cars in Sichuan province.
That's the Sichuan province beyond the mountains in western China, next to Tibet.
And after many excursions in there afoot,
finally pinned down.
The missionaries had built very beautiful city streets for China.

There was 400 missionaries in that area of all denominations, and they had cooperated in the opposition to the home boards in buying land around a given area and establishing a university in the center
which was owned by all of them, but administered by a special group representative of these groups.
And the West China Union University was an outstanding institution.
And they had provided the incentive for people to be more forward looking.
And for that reason, I was able to sell them on a program of cars.
And I put the first cars in.
18 months to deliver it all.
Some of them had to be, packages had to be broken down in 100-pound packages and carried over the mountains on man's back and put back together again.
But that was the last program we had in China, and the Communist Revolution came in at that time.
It actually came in in 25, and it reached central China by 27.
who forced out practically all the missionaries from the Orient, and most businesses were curtailed.
I came home on leave at that time after four years.
This would have been on leave from Gillespie.
Yes.
That was a practice in the Orient to send you home for six months, expenses paid after every four years.
I think that originally originated in India, where the climate was so severe that it affected the physical capacity of people to stay in that hot climate so manya long period.
But in it, the British customs rather prevailed throughout the Orient in those days, and so that's one of the things that all companies did, all foreign companies did.
They had families that sent the whole work home for six months vacation on full pay, and then come back.
But while I was home, the things broke loose there.
The company lost $5 billion on the breaking of the market for shellac in India.
My firm was, had been in from the beginning.
The importation of shellac was very important in the, in the record business.

at that time, and radio began to come in, and the record business went on the skids, and the shellac market broke, and that had some effect on the firm, and then the speculation in wood oil, which had been interrupted by the Communist Revolution in 25, 27, 28, and so they sold out Spencer Kellogg and left one man in charge out there to wind up.
So I was out of a job yet.
Could we stop at this point of your career and kind of back up a little bit to your days on campus?
I did get away from that, didn't I?
Okay.
I'm sorry.
You should have stopped me.
Well, I was interested in your story about going to China and your activities there.
You said that your train arrived in College Station at like four o'clock in the morning and it was a representative from Ross Hall.
Was this a common practice?
From Foster Hall.
Foster Hall, I'm sorry.
I think it was.
It was a common practice.
I did practice it myself in later years, but I noticed that Foster Hall was one of the older halls, you see, and Mitchell Hall and two others were modern, had steam heat.
Foster Hall, Ross Hall, and the band hall, what was that name in Austin Hall?
Mm-hmm.
were the first buildings on the campus, and they had wood stoves and wash pans and a washstand.
You had to go downstairs to get your water and bring it up.
You had to go out and bring your wood up.
And that was one of the real activities of all the freshmen, is to keep the wood boxes full on all those four floors.
And so naturally, the other dormitories didn't have to work.
People didn't have to
everybody wanted to get in the more modern places.
And all those country boys, so-called, we got over in Foster Hall.
You were recruited for Foster Hall then, or one of the other ones, by one of the upperclassmen, I take it.
Yeah.
I think of his name one of these days.
I mean, I can't call it, I see him, I can visualize him.
So it was a practice primarily then of the older dormitories to be at the train station and recruit their freshmen so they'd have somebody to fill the wood box and carry the water for them.
That was the assumption.
Now I don't know whether that was actually true or not.
Would you describe a typical day?
when you were in school.
I would like for you to include the time of getting up and the procedure of getting up and what you did then and as far as going to meals and the time you spent in class and what you did otherwise.
Well, of course, you know, we wore blue shirts, blue shirts with a blue uniform, a gray uniform, I guess you'd call it gray, had a bow tie.
Most of us never had a bow tie before and it was a learning tie, but
Reveille, you were out of bed, and you had to get down, and you had to have that bow tie on.
Some of the upperclassmen would go down there and weren't dressed that way, but got away with it.
But we freshmen, we had to have that bow tie.
I learned to tie a bow tie running downstairs.
How much time did you have between Reveille and the time you had to be there?
I don't recall, but I think it was five minutes.
It may have been ten, but I doubt it.
I think it seemed like it was five minutes.
So you had to get out of bed and get dressed and be down there.
Get down there, yes.
But it may have been ten minutes, but as I recall, I think it was five minutes.
We were always in line.
I was always in line when the vehicle sounded.
We had setting up exercises, too.
This was right after you got down in the line?
Yeah, we got down in the line.
We were all accounted for.
Then we had setting up exercises and dismissed and went back to clean our rooms and got the next call for breakfast.
And then we had formation and marched to the hall for breakfast.
And then when we came back, we were supposed to have an inspection.
I forgot at what time, before we went to class.
And they had an inspection of the room.
Everything had to be cleaned.
Not the regular inspectionSunday mornings we had a regular inspection by the incumbent, but whoever was on daily dutywhat do we call that?
At daily duty, somebody came and inspected the room.
See, the bed was made up Wouldn't that have been the officer of the day?
Officer of the day, what I'm trying to say.
Gee, I'll remember that, officer of the day.
And then we went to classes.
And of course, we had different schedules.
Some had, most of us had an eight o'clock class.
But the class schedule followed until four o'clock.
And then we had drill.
And that was pretty regular, five days a week, except on Friday was a dress parade.
And that was, in the wintertime, of course, it was
They didn't have the setting up exercises when it was severe weather, but that was the ordinary run of things of the day.
Three times the mess hall.
After the mess hall, for the first week, of course, we had to go to the chapel for instructions and various organizations announcing their programs and things of that kind.
But there wasn't much argument in the way of private argument.
There was no secret organization.
It literally formed the clubs, the Fort Worth Club, the Lamb County Club, people from that group.
And they had meetings in the dormitory room betweenit was usually in the evening between seven thirty and ten when taps sounded.
I don't know of any other activity except in the fall when the football gamewe were all out for that.
And later, as basketball developed, we went to basketball games on the campus.
There wasn't anything off the campus.
It was confined to the campus.
Were there any facilities in the Y, say, for YMCA?
The YMCA had a swimming pool, which was not there the first year.
But it was the second, and I never did get in that pool.
They had Sunday school classes after chapel in the YMCA.
